Saul Nachman

Dear Reader

If you're reading this, it's likely I've sent it your way – but if you've stumbled upon it and find it pleasing, feel free to contact me.

Let's assume you are the intended reader and I am applying for a job at your organisation.

Why you should hire me

Well, first, I've sent you a lovely website, that I made, which demonstrates some skill on my part. If that doesn't impress you, let me tell you a bit about myself.

Who even is this guy?

I was twenty-nine; it was four in the morning; I asked a close developer friend how long it would take to become one. ‘A year’, he said – so, having programmed a bit as hobby (some Python – a ROT-13 decoder and a curry-recipe scaler/coster – HTML and CSS) for about a year, I quit my job as an editor.

A year wasn't the best estimate – he's in software, so I forgive him the scope creep.

Learning a new profession takes time and dedication. I partnered with my friend in the ensuing period of panic and doubt, working on anything I get could my hands on and soaking myself in all available wisdom for succeeding at my new-chosen vocation.

I learned well.

Working in tech

I never thought I'd work in tech. I never thought I'd fall in love with tech – I studied philosophy and literature and English teaching before working as an academic editor and legal examiner.

But I did. It turns out making beautiful, clever or elegant things all day is very satisfying; challenging things even moreso. I get meaning from many places but substantial meaning from being good at this, which strikes me as something one wants in an employee.

Why you should hire me: part deux

Being driven, I offer:

  • Professionalism
  • Determination
  • Attention to detail
  • High standards of work
  • Hunger to learn and improve
  • Organisational vision
  • Great lists

To my surprise, I now think I'm quite good at this – and I'd like a chance to prove myself right (right being something I dearly enjoy being) at your organisation, to the benefit of us both.

Relevant experience

IO Digital

Senior full-stack developer

April 2019 – present
Role/responsibilities
Duties
  • Leadership
  • Standard setting
  • Architecture
  • Mentoring
  • Design systems
  • Client communication
  • Devops

Averly & design systems: At present, I'm working on a Vue/Nuxt PWA project called ‘Averly’, which is intended as a marketplace to mediate between tenants, landlords and agencies. I lead a team of four, including a remote developer, and the intention is to grow the team as the project progresses.

Beyond my immediate project, I've also been tasked with developing the default stack for new projects, including tooling. One intention for this project is that it provides a component library for use on other projects at IO, and as such I am tasked with creating a design system for our long-term use.

NML (New Media Labs)

Developer

Oct 2017 – April 2019
Role/responsibilities
Duties
  • Azure automation
  • FE development
  • App prototyping
  • Project leadership
  • Client communication
  • Cross-project devops
  • Site building

African Rainbow Life: I was front-end lead/architect for the construction of a React offline-first progressive web application for African Rainbow Life for signing up and managing insurance applications (internal use by agents and supervisors). This involved training and guiding four other developers in React, ES6, functional programming and JavaScript applications in general.

DevOps: Between d3 and the African Rainbow Life project, I was given devops duties at NML. Successes include: 1) transitioning the front-end team's component libraries (Jekyll/Ruby) from RDP/SFTP deployments to cloud-based push-to-build pipelines with scoped cloud services; and 2) automating deployment via Powershell (and developing a user interface in Team City) for the Horizon/Graphite financial-services intermediary, with the deployment to Azure of a configured virtual machines and web api services – over multiple environmental configs – along with logging, storage, automated secret-keeping, disk encryption, the network and DNS.

Dubai Design District: I was lead developer for the Dubai Design District (d3) project (SiteCore/.NET/SXA/Solr/React stack), involving architecture choices, training a junior developer, operating full stack, API integration and delivering a very fine looking project which is now in legal dispute after the client... well, ask me for the story sometime.

Saxobank: I was tasked with building a dynamic, configurable-by-metadata form-builder for on-boarding Saxobank clients that maintained state over browser reloads built in Angular.

Pillbox Design/Freelance

Developer

May 2015 – Oct 2017
Role/responsibilities
Duties
  • Site maintenance
  • Content management
  • Feature production
  • Client communication
  • Proposal writing
  • Site building

On quitting editing, Jeff Webster (Pillbox Design) and I formed a partnership where I did (ad hoc) site maintenance, feature development and content work (management as well as writing and editing) for his/our clients. Where there was opportunity to do feature development work (Creation Wines, Solid Green, Mark Gevisser) or work on larger projects (5A, Silver Forest, Ankh), I was able to take on tasks he had grown out of.

Under the mentorship of a skilled professional, I was able to grow quickly. Independent work in this period includes AirconStudio and Fireplace Studio.

I used this period to study the industry I was entering, learning and investing in WordPress customisation, REST, HTML, CSS/SCSS, responsive design, JavaScript (jQuery and Vanilla.js) and TypeScript (Angular 2).

These days most of my work life is spent writing and architecting PWAs, so I spend a lot of time with JS – especially state management, component design and API integrations – now having developed in three major frameworks (Vue/React/Angular), popular build tools (Gatsby/Nuxt/Webpack etc.) and with many major libraries (Redux/RxJs/Vuex/Eslint/Jest etc.) and paradigms (functional style; TDD).

Still, as a once freelancer who had to do it all, I have a deep passion for good CSS, typography and design. I believe to be a front-end expert means being a CSS-first developer – and while I am very proud of my JavaScript knowledge, and only get to write CSS occasionally, if I can do something in CSS, I will.

I'm fully capable at mobile/responsive development and am very capable with mockups, basic asset preparation and know Illustrator well enough to make logos/icons in an emergency.

For a too-brief period before I was redistributed I was entrusted to develop devops at NML – I think because I get grumpy about things working badly or unreliably, and over the time waste and errors involved in manual deployments.

Unfortunately, I'm very good at front-end JavaScript architecture, so I keep getting pulled away from this interest to run projects. Nevertheless, I spent three months buried in Azure documentation, the Azure CLI, PowerShell and TeamCity developing automation scripts for a fairly complex set of resources and enjoyed it very much.

In my current role at IO Digital, as project lead, I'm responsible for our ops strategies – though this work is work I'll be picking up in earnest in the next few months.

    .NET

I consider myself a full-stack developer, but my relationship to API development needs explanation, despite architecture and code review being part of my mandate at IO. In what's become a running theme, I'm very good at front-end JavaScript architecture, so people keep asking me to do that instead.

Nevertheless here's the oddball list of things I've done: 1) templating in PHP, Express and Razorviews; 2) REST endpoints for microservices, and one custom search endpoint exposing WordPress for a shop site; 3) HTTP relays in .NET; 4) database tutorials in three languages with both MySQL and Postgres (never taken a database I've designed to production; hardly ever get to write SQL); 5) endpoints managing OAuth connection to and sessions for Azure Active Directory in Express; and 6) training in data-layer architecture in C# and Entity Framework

Other skills

Writing and editing

  • Writing
  • Editing
  • Client communication
  • Documentation
  • Reading law

As a former academic editor and legal examiner, I hope it stands not as arrogance but mere fact when I say I am extremely proficient at writing. It's a valuable skill in its own right, but it also makes me a better developer and team-member – in that my code is neat, organised, consistent, clear and well commented, and in that I am a contributor to and driver of documentation.

An editor's role substantially involves typography and layout. These skills don't go away, and contribute heavily to my eye for beautiful, clean, error-free front-end design.

I can communicate effectively with clients – either in my capacity as an employee or as a designated agent – in a way that reflects well on those I represent.

Other pertinent experience

Milpark Education

Academic editor

June 2014 – May 2015
Role/responsibilities
Duties
  • In-house editing
  • Quality review
  • HR textbooks
  • Writing HR chapters
  • Resourcing writers
  • Styling & typography

At Milpark Education, a for-profit university, I was made responsible for the quality and construction of the human resources qualification course materials, including it's textbook.

This involved a variety of duties, including finding academics to do or review chapters of the book – as well as editing and checking their work for plagiarism. Where we could not find someone to write a chapter, I was expected to write place-holding material for the year's edition myself.

In addition, the editing team served as in-house editors for the academic staff, making sure papers or articles they submitted looked good and were ready for journal submission – and making sure the institution was not embarrassed by plagiarism.

References

Lara Raffaelli Lara Raffaelli – lara.raffaelli@milpark.ac.za
Editor-in-Chief, Milpark Education

Exigent Legal Services

Legal Examiner

June 2012 – June 2014
Role/responsibilities
Duties
  • Proofreading
  • Legal referencing
  • Layout
  • Styling consistency

I worked for Exigent as an outsourced legal examiner for London banking law firm Linklaters. It was an intense and interesting time, though I'd never go back to it. Linklaters demanded both speed and quality, and the pressure was intense to achieve both.

The work – which involved reading a variety of contract types (financial instruments, shipping, loan, merger & acquisition, stock issuance and prospectus, estate planning) contracts for spelling, style, layout and grammar errors, as well as for correct convention for the contract type – is normally the responsibility of paralegals at smaller firms.

References

Cassandra Weir Cassandra Weir – cassandraweir@gmail.com
Line Manager, Exigent
